t: Remember*pn your Creator in*ld the days of your youth, before*ln the days of trouble come and*ld the years approach when you will say, “I*ld find no pleasure in them”—
before*ln the sun and the light and*ld the moon and the stars grow dark, and*ld the clouds return after the rain;
when*ln the keepers of the house tremble, and*ld the strong men stoop, when*ln the grinders cease because they are few, and*ld those looking through the windows grow dim;
when*ln the doors to the street are closed and*ld the sound of grinding fades; when*ln people rise up at the sound of birds, but*ld all their songs grow faint;

when*ln people are afraid of heights and*ld of dangers in the streets; when*ln the almond tree blossoms and*ld the grasshopper drags itself along and*ld desire no longer is stirred. Then*ln people go to their eternal home and*ld mourners go about the streets.
Remember*pn him—before the silver cord is severed, and*ld the golden bowl is broken; before*ln the pitcher is shattered at the spring, and*ld the wheel broken at the well,
and*ln the dust returns to the ground it came from, and*ld the spirit returns to God who gave it.
“Meaningless!*pn Meaningless!” says the Teacher. “Everything*ld is meaningless!”
Not*p only was the Teacher wise, but he also imparted knowledge to the people. He pondered and searched out and set in order many proverbs.
The Teacher searched to find just the right words, and what he wrote was upright and true.
The*p words of the wise are like goads, their collected sayings like firmly embedded nails—given by one shepherd.
Be warned, my son, of anything in addition to them. Of*p making many books there is no end, and much study wearies the body.
Now*pn all has been heard; here*ld is the conclusion of the matter: Fear*ln God and keep his commandments, for*ld this is the duty of all mankind.
For*ln God will bring every deed into judgment, including*ld every hidden thing, whether*ld it is good or evil.
